thread.title: Cory Bernardi and George Christensen's Q Society event stirs anger at Victoria University
thread.title_full: Cory Bernardi and George Christensen's Q Society event stirs anger at Victoria University

author: Tom McIlroy
title: Cory Bernardi and George Christensen's Q Society event stirs anger at Victoria University
text:
CSIRO errors risk Aboriginal rock art CSIRO errors risk Aboriginal rock art 
A series of CSIRO errors has put Burrup Peninsula's collection of indigenous rock art at risk from atmospheric acid levels. More videos Cory Bernardi dinner disrupted by protestors 
More than a hundred anti-racism protesters clashed with people heading to a secret fundraising dinner in Melbourne for the anti-Islam organisation Q Society. 
The "Halal Choices" dinner, part of a two-night fundraising tour billed as part of a defence of free speech, was raising money for the legal defence bill of outspoken Q Society member Kirralie Smith, who is being sued for defamation over videos she made about halal certification practices. 
Literary journal Overland published a letter of protest expressing alarm and disappointment to the university council and vice-chancellor Peter Dawkins from 75 current and former staff and students, campus organisations, Victorian Greens MP Colleen Hartland and writer Jeff Sparrow. Related Content Ross Cameron defends calling Liberal Party 'a gay club' 
"The Q Society is well known for associating Islam with terrorism and lobbying Parliament to ban halal certification," the letter said. 
"In 2014, the Q Society toured far-right Dutch MP Geert Wilders, who advocates a total ban on Muslim migration. At the Q Society fundraising dinner held in Sydney on Thursday night, Larry Pickering, cartoonist and VIP guest said: 'Let's be honest, I can't stand Muslims'. Advertisement 
"Cory Bernardi, former Liberal Party senator, was a keynote speaker at Friday night's event in Melbourne. Bernardi has been a vocal opponent of Islam, opposes reproductive freedom for women and has linked same-sex marriage to bestiality." 
The letter said the event breached policies which forbid university facilities from being made available for unlawful activities and events which are in conflict or incompatible with university values. SHARE
